Authors:
Palesa Lesuthu, Providence Moyo, Francois Halleen, Lizel
Mostert, Chris Frederik Jakobus Spies
Title:
Diaporthe sp. novem and first report of Diaporthe cynaroidis,
Diaporthe novem and Diaporthe serafiniae on grapevines in South
Africa
Abstract:
Diaporthe species cause Phomopsis cane and leaf spot and
Phomopsis dieback on grapevines. Symptoms of these diseases have
increasing been observed over the past few years. In order to assess the
current status of Diaporthe on grapevines in the Western Cape Province
of South Africa, isolations were made from dormant grafted nursery
vines, dormant rootstock canes and dying or dead spurs of field vines.
Cultures identified as Diaporthe based on morphological features were
identified to species level by sequencing the internal transcribed
spacer region and, for a representative sub-sample of isolates, the
beta-tubulin region. Phylogenetic analysis of the combined ITS and
beta-tubulin data revealed nine Diaporthe species associated with
grapevines during this survey, of which one represents an undescribed
species and three others are reported on grapevines in South Africa for
the first time (D. novem, D. cynaroidis and D. serafiniae).
Morphological features of pycnidia produced in culture were measured and
compared with published descriptions. Three sets of species-specific
primers were designed for PCR identification of D. ampelina, D. ambigua
and D. foeniculina, which were the most common species. Pathogenicity
studies conducted on detached grapevine shoots indicated that, of the
species tested D. ampelina, D. novem and the new sp. were the most
pathogenic.
